abstract: Study conducted by Misdemeanor Justice Project at John Jay College of Criminal Justice finds overall number of arrests, stops, moving violations and criminal summonses has fallen significantly in New York City over period of four years, driven primarily by sharp decline in stop-and-frisk searches; stops have fallen to 1.82 million in 2014 from a peak of 2.63 million in 2011, showing progress toward reduction goal articulated by Police Commissioner William J Bratton.
lead_paragraph: The overall number of arrests, stops, moving violations and criminal summonses has dropped by more than 800,000 over the past four years, according to the study.

headline.main: Decline in Stop-and-Frisk Tactic Drives Drop in Police Actions in New York, Study Says
